title: Che poi cos'è, precisamente, che amavo di quell'estate?
body:
Se ci penso i ricordi virano in giallo come le vecchie polaroid, i contorni sfumano un po’ e resta solo il bello, così dolce. Le urla scalmanate dell’ultimo giorno di scuola, quando suonava la campanella e si correva fuori al grido di: “È finitaaaaaaaaa!“. Il mio primo concerto. I Depeche. 


Tornare a casa a piedi, da solo, con le chiavi in tasca (fantascienza! Roba che oggi, se la mamma/la tata/la nonna non recuperano il pupo direttamente dalla mano della maestra puoi dire ciaociao alla patria podestà).
Fermarsi in edicola per comprare le figurine Panini dei Puffi, e in panetteria per la focaccia e l’uovo kinder, che è ora di fare merenda. Inizia BimBumBam, con Mila&Shiro.
E la pizza scontata da San Martino, con i tavolini fuori, le candele e i wurstel!
La sfilata del circo in paese, con gli elefanti, Moira Orfei, i pagliacci e i cavalli bianchi tutti bardati. Andare allo spettacolo della sera e applaudire fino a spelarsi i palmi delle mani. Salire sull’elefantino durante l’intervallo e scoprire che non è per nulla morbido, anzi: punge come un’istrice, che ci ha delle setole durissime e tu hai su i pantaloncini corti, quelli rossi con l’ancora blu. Ecco svelato il motivo per cui mi ritrovo con quella faccia contrita (occhio spalancato e labbra strette) stampata da quasi trent’anni sulla classica foto di rito.
Ogni volta che la vedo rido. E Bianca e Bernie al cinema all’aperto, con la libellula Evinrude. Senza pop-corn che nonsiamomicagliamericani ma con la Bomboniera della Algida. Da affrontare con parsimonia, che sono solo sei pezzi.

title: Valentini Elettrodomestici
body:
Nel 1955 il televisore arrivò anche a casa mia.

Fummo fra i primi ad avere un apparecchio televisivo. Acquistato da Valentini elettrodomestici che aveva il negozio in Corso Umberto I° (oggi Corso Giovanni XXIII°), quasi di fronte all’attuale negozio di dolciumi Vulpitta. In città era uno dei pochi negozi di quel genere. Gli elettrodomestici in vendita consistevano soprattutto in apparecchi radio, radiogrammofoni, giradischi, cucine a gas, cucine elettriche, aspirapolvere, i primi frigoriferi e la vera novità: i televisori.

Era considerato un lusso possedere un televisore e fu un grosso sacrificio economico quell’acquisto, per mio padre.

La maggior parte delle persone andava al bar o presso qualche circolo per vedere i programmi di maggior interesse.

Vittorio Antonio, mio fratello maggiore, due anni ci dividevano, aveva il cuore malato per i postumi di febbri reumatiche. Aveva un soffio al cuore trasformatosi poi in scompenso cardiaco. Aveva 14 anni e non era riuscito, a causa della malattia iniziata nel 1949 e che lo costringeva spesso a letto, a terminare la Va classe elementare e neppure la preparazione alla Prima Comunione che ricevette, in una rara pausa della malattia, nel 1950 da Don Calandrini, a Roma nella Basilica di San Pietro, durante il pellegrinaggio organizzato dalle ACLI riminesi per l’anno Santo e al quale partecipò l’intera nostra famiglia.

Col tempo le sue condizioni peggiorarono; i cardiologi e il medico di famiglia, dott. Aulo Donati, gli imposero riposo assoluto ed evitare qualunque sforzo e divieto di camminare. Quando si sentiva un po’ meglio, per fargli prendere un po’ d’aria e cercare di distrarlo, il babbo lo prendeva in braccio e con l’auto, una Fiat Balilla 1100, acquistata di seconda mano, lo portava a spasso.

Quindi il televisore era arrivato per rendergli le lunghe giornate passate nel letto o sul sofà, più leggere e meno noiose. Fra i suoi passatempi c’era la lettura e la collezione di francobolli che l’amico Giancarlo Morolli (poi diventato un giudice internazionale di filatelia e colonna della ditta Bolaffi) gli portava dal locale circolo filatelico cittadino.

Le trasmissioni televisive cominciavano alle 17.30 con la “TV dei Ragazzi” che durava 1 ora e mezza, poi si interrompevano per riprendere alle 20,45 e andavano avanti fino alle 23,00. La domenica i programmi cominciavano alle ore 11,00. La pubblicità non esisteva, solo dal 1957 inizierà con “Carosello”.

Il televisore, un Philips, era grosso, di legno scuro con una cornice di legno più chiaro; era un 17 pollici, il canale era unico e non esisteva il telecomando. Il ripetitore delle onde tv più vicino era a Monte Venda, vicino a Verona e la ricezione del segnale era scarso e in condizioni di meteo perturbato con molto sfarfallìo. A volte si vedeva e non si sentiva, o viceversa. Ricordo di un Festival della Canzone Italiana (San Remo); la stanza era piena di persone (i vicini di casa), abbiamo seguito il programma col televisore, cercando la migliore sintonizzazione delle immagini che però escludeva l’audio e con la radio per l’ascolto delle canzoni. E con la combinazione dei due apparecchi accesi, riuscimmo a goderci il Festival.

L’antenna televisiva, posta sul tetto, era leggerissima, di alluminio e veniva letteralmente mangiata dalla salsedine marina e doveva essere sostituita ogni anno.

Ricordo attorno al letto di Vittorio noi di famiglia e anche qualche vicino di casa in occasione di trasmissioni che suscitavano più interesse, quali quiz (Duecento al secondo, Lascia e raddoppia, il Musichiere) o anche avvenimenti sportivi.

Vittorio seguiva con particolare interesse la rubrica religiosa “Sguardo sul mondo” condotta, con estrema naturalezza e simpatia dal frate francescano Padre Mariano e “Una risposta per voi”, programma diretto dal professor Armando Cutolo, uomo di cultura e critico teatrale, discepolo del filosofo Benedetto Croce, che con un linguaggio semplice condito da una simpaticissima “verve” napoletana rispondeva a domande e curiosità che gli venivano proposte. Poi gli sceneggiati televisivi tratti con grande fedeltà dai classici della letteratura.

All’epoca, per il cuore, non esistevano le operazioni o applicazioni di protesi o ancora meglio i trapianti dei nostri tempi e anche se sotto il controllo dei migliori cardiologi (ricordo il prof. Dagnini a Bologna e il prof. Poppi ad Ancona) che con le loro parcelle hanno prosciugato le finanze di famiglia e la costante presenza del medico di famiglia, fra l’altro amico d’infanzia del babbo, Vittorio si spense improvvisamente nella sera del 25 febbraio 1958, all’età di 17 anni, dopo 9 anni di sofferta malattia. Improvvisamente ma non inaspettatamente: i nostri genitori già da molti mesi erano stati avvisati che per Vittorio non c’era più alcuna speranza di vita.

title: Pane, zucchero e vino
body:
are la merenda a metà pomeriggio per noi bambini era una prassi irrinunciabile.

Allora abitavo in via Monte Titano e frequentavo la scuola elementare dalla Maestre Pie dell’Addolorata, in via Santa Chiara. La scuola era a tempo pieno: rincasavo verso le quattro del pomeriggio. Ricordo la mamma che mi aspettava con la merenda pronta.

Nelle giornate fredde ci accoglieva (me e i miei fratelli) con le patate americane cotte nell’acqua, ancora bollenti (la patata dolce che per quei tempi era una novità). Con quelle ci riscaldavamo le mani e lo stomaco.

Ma la merenda che mi è rimasta nella memoria e che è sempre stata per me la più gradita era: pane, vino e zucchero. Mamma tagliava in due una pagnottina di pane comune simile alle odierne mantovane, con un cucchiaio le bagnava con il vino rosso, che in altra epoca ho conosciuto chiamarsi sangiovese, e le cospargeva coprendole di buon zucchero.


Sotto i denti, il morbido pane, lo scricchiare dello zucchero e il sapore del vino creavano un perfetto connubio; anche oggi qualche volta ripeto quel rito, ma non riesco più a ritrovare il piacere di quei tempi; forse perchè oggi non riesco più ad assaporare la gioia di quei semplici sapori contaminati dal moderno modo di vivere.

Quella merenda è stata per me e i miei fratelli il primo approccio col vino.

Ricordo il nonno che a tavola diceva: dai un goz ad vein, ma che burdel.

Penso che la mamma, prima di bagnare il pane, allungasse il vino con un po’ d’acqua.

title: “scusi ma lei non è il figlio del bagnino?”
body:
Ebbene sì, sono figlio del bagnino poi divenuto fratello del bagnino quando mio fratello è subentrato nell’attività. Ancora oggi, a 59 anni suonati, mi capita di dover rispondere a vecchi clienti reincontrati per caso, conosciuti cinquant’anni fa, “scusi ma lei non è il figlio del bagnino?”

Il che la dice lunga sul ruolo del bagnino che rimane un vero e proprio tratto identitario della riminesità.
Che piaccia o no!

Negli anni 50 la parte sexy spettava all’uomo con gli slip copripube, scosciati, uniti sui fianchi da un cordellino distrattamente rallentato…le donne, col costume in pudica tinta unita, di LANA! Poi sostituito da quello di filanca, con un doppio riporto che garantiva la totale copertura del ventre e della peluria più intima e selvaggia. Eh sì perché i peli, allora, sul petto degli uomini o altrove nelle donne, stimolavano i sensori della sensualità.

Erano anni, quelli 50, in cui si usciva dalla guerra e lo spirito di conservazione era più forte di quello critico e/o creativo. Difficile percepire come impresa qualcosa che avveniva sulla sabbia. Ricordo uno dei bar di Marina Centro, una struttura in legno che i titolari, desolati per i mancati guadagni, non riuscivano a rivendere. I turisti si avvicinavano per qualche aranciata, i bambini per un bicchiere d’acqua, il resto veniva da casa trasportato con borse cariche di frutta, panini, ciotole e “cartocci”.

Non c’era ancora la concezione del “settore” coordinato per cui ombrelloni e sedie sdraio, da subito ribattezzate “sdrai”, variopinti nei colori, venivano rimpiazzati quando i rammendi e le riparazioni effettuate direttamente dal bagnino “non tenevano più”.

Sulla gara dei clienti per accaparrarsi quelli nuovi, dirò poi. Idem per poter avere l’ombrellone in prima fila, il primo status simbol del dopoguerra riminese.

Sui birri, i zanza molto si è detto in “Falce, martello e lasagne”. Ma in spiaggia nasce il latin lover di casa nostra.

E’ il bagnino il primo vero simbolo del madeinitaly e, nel nostro caso, del madeinrimini. Abbronzatura ineguagliabile, fisico possente, muscoli alimentati dal sollevamento di ombrelloni, sdrai, pedane, paletti. In piedi sul moscone, petto in fuori, braccia ai remi, appariva il dio Nettuno, con una carica erotica che sprigionava dall’odore inconfondibile della pelle, misto di salsedine, ambra solare e sudore fresco.

title: Gossip raffinato in prima fila al Miramare
body:
Quella più vicina al mare era la fila del gossip raffinato, dei costumi all’ultima moda indossati sotto il “prendi sole”, degli odori provenienti dalle prime creme solari di qualità, dell’abbronzatura marrone scuro, del linguaggio che, dal classico, andava assumendo i toni e i modi importati dai film americani o dalle prime commedie all’italiana della nostra cinematografia, dopo il periodo del neorealismo. Arrivava “l’aperitivo” mentre le “corna” escono dal tabù.
Eh sì: per le corna, la spiaggia era e resta la cornice più naturale, per viverle e, sicuramente, per parlarne…

title: Irripetibili
body:
Scriveva Fellini che “osc-ia dlamadona ha lo stesso fascino esotico di Rashomon”.
Ma per rimanere nella nebbia felliniana di Amarcord, quelle più a rischio di sparizione sono le persone che per uno o più motivi sono diventate personaggi irripetibili della comunità.


Si sorrideva al passaggio di Paolino (mudaja) preoccupandosi quando non lo si vedeva per giorni perché “l’è bon, un fa de mel ma nissun” mentre in altri casi il personaggio si identificava con la funzione o coi tratti del carattere: “cla bicicletta l’ora che ta la porta dalla Minghina” dava un’indicazione chiara per tutti, non da meno Biscarein.
Così “a vag da la Mele” stava per “vado a comprare le poveracce nella Piazzetta” (omonima) mentre “ci come Cutmein” la diceva tutta dei saccentoni di turno. O Putac che, povero in canna tanto da dormire sotto una barca, spiccava per la sua generosità che lo portava a regalare la sua modestissima razione di pane.

title: La radio
body:
Ancor oggi se voglio gustare ogni sfumatura di una voce, di un suono musicale o canoro, devo chiudere gli occhi ed evitare ogni distrazione provocata dalle immagini. In questo modo mi è possibile cogliere l’impostazione, la varietà dei toni vocali, la gravità, la leggerezza… fino ad arrivare all’età, al sesso dell’emittente.


Capita anche coi films… dalla colonna sonora che accompagna i titoli di testa, ascoltata da una stanza diversa da quella di proiezione, si può indovinare il genere: commedia, western, musical, comico, giallo, drammatico, storico, cappa e spada, ecc.. e anche la qualità del film. Difficile che un buon film abbia una musica poco avvincente.

E’ l’orecchio sviluppato di chi, come me, è cresciuto con la radio di casa. Radio Marelli o Radio Geloso, quella ad incasso di legno, con due manopole: una per la ricerca delle “stazioni” e una per regolare il volume.

Più che un elettrodomestico era un mobile, con sopra il centrino, la statuina di gesso ed il suo “odore” emanato dal surriscaldamento delle valvole. Ho avuto anche radio senza incasso, con le valvole e l’altoparlante in bella vista..le realizzava mio zio Gino, radioamatore e operatore al Cinema Sant’Agostino e al Cinema Italia, entrambi in Via Cairoli. Nel primo proiettavano film western, ogni anno gli stessi, quelli con la pellicola sbiadita orlata di giallo, tutta la serie di David Crockett, di Jerry Lewis e Dean Martin… le pellicole erano talmente vecchie che spesso facevano “il quadro”… si bloccavano sullo schermo. Gli spettatori, anche loro sempre gli stessi, s’imbufalivano “dai Gino nu fa è pataca”. Era che lo zio durante la proiezione, riceveva la ”morosa” di turno e, diversamente impegnato, non si accorgeva del “quadro.” Ecco perché mi faceva bussare quando, nei pomeriggi, gli portavo la merenda.

Al Cinema Italia arrivavano, di seconda mano, i “filmoni” che avevano avuto la “prima” al Supercinema (Savoia) all’Eliseo, al Fulgor: I dieci comandamenti, Rocco e i suoi fratelli, la Dolce Vita. Era l’epoca d’oro. Nelle sale si proiettava quattro volte al giorno, nel pomeriggio alle 14,30 e alle 17 e la sera alle 20,40 e alle 22,30. Tra una proiezione e l’altra veniva trasmesso “film Luce” … una sorta di notiziario edulcorato, in bianco e nero che riportava gli avvenimenti d’attualità con la voce fuori campo di Renato Turi, attore, doppiatore e, per l’appunto, personaggio radiofonico.

Ma era la radio a suggellare l’autenticità delle notizie: “T’è sintì cus chiadet ma la radio?” “L’è véra, i l’ha dét ma la radio!”. Per questo, forse, si ascoltava con un rispetto quasi reverenziale, soprattutto da parte degli uomini, gli unici che, rientrati dal lavoro, potevano permettersi di ascoltare le trasmissioni, seduti davanti come se, al posto del mobile parlante, ci fossero le persone in carne ed ossa. Il Giornale Radio, il Bollettino dei Naviganti… erano momenti quasi solenni, i bambini venivano zittiti (sta zet ch’eè bà l’è ma la radio), le donne smettevano i lavori di casa più rumorosi… anche perché i mobili della cucina erano scarsi e i tegami venivano impilati uno dentro l’altro per cui, togliendone uno dal mezzo della pila, il più della volte cascavano tutti. E l’ora esatta, la vera ora esatta, era quella annunciata dall’Uccellino della Rai.

Per le donne la radio era un’occasione di rivincita, compensavano, con l’ascolto, l’estraniazione dal resto del mondo. I personaggi radiofonici animavano le “chiacchiere” del pomeriggio, finite le faccende. Era il momento del caffè, quello di Giovannini, magari corretto col mistrà tenuto nel bottiglione quando i soldi lo permettevano o della Vecchina (il surrogato) così chiamata per l’immagine della vecchia dai capelli bianchi che appariva sul sacchetto della confezione. La radio creava il sottofondo e offriva gli argomenti.

I cantanti, alla radio, si esibivano dal “vivo” accompagnati da orchestre di alto livello. Ogni maestro: Cinico Angelini (quello di “C’è una chiesetta amor”), Riz Ortolani, Armando Fragna…aveva la sua sigla di apertura e la sua squadra di cantanti. Tra gli ascoltatori si erano create le fazioni sostenitrici di Nilla Pizza e Carla Boni. La prima classica all’Italiana, le seconda già genere swing. Carla Boni sposò Gina Latilla che, pare, avesse una passione per Nilla Pizzi mentre Katina Ranieri, si diceva, avesse lasciato marito e figli per Riz Ortolani, Tonina Torielli, detta la Caramellaia per il precedente lavoro di operaia, replicava, con scarso successo, Nilla Pizza, Flo’ Sandos, moglie di Natalino Otto anticipava i ritmi “americani”. Fazioni anche per i sostenitori di Claudio Villa e Luciano Tavoli. Più netta la resistenza delle casalinghe verso i cantanti cosiddetti confidenziali: Fausto Cigliano, Yula de Palma, considerati “poco dotati” dal punto di vista canoro.

La radio era il contatto con il mondo esterno che, per la mancanza di immagini e di cronache fedeli, continuava ad essere un mondo di fantasia. Cantanti, attori, venivano “immaginati” sulla base delle sensazioni suscitate dalla voce. Ricordo la voce calda, suadente di Neil Sedaka. Lo pensavo simile all’attore “bello” dei film americani in bianco e nero, da William Holden a Robert Taylor. Me lo sono ritrovato, in foto, basso, stempiato e impomatato, con un sorriso prestampato tipo uomo da “banco”, gli mancava solo la penna dietro l’orecchio.

La sera, dopo cena, ci si riuniva (le donne) attorno la radio ad ascoltare le “commedie”. Erano rappresentazioni dei classici della letteratura e drammaturgia italiana ma anche inglese e russa: da Cime Tempestose a Delitto e Castigo. Tutto era affidato al suono, compresi in rumori del vento in tempesta, degli zoccoli dei cavalli che venivano riprodotti da un “rumorista”. Le voci prevalenti erano quelle di Nando Gazzolo, Anna Miserocchi, Paolo Stoppa e Rina Morelli.

Durante il pranzo si ascoltava Radio Capodistria quella della musica “dedicata” per compleanni e anniversari e dove ricorrevano i “classici” (Mamma), il folklore (Romagna Mia) e gli inni politici (Bandiera Rossa). E poi c’erano le trasmissioni di “compagnia” a partire da “Sorella Radio” che veniva presentata da Silvio Gigli, in diretta dai Sanatori di tutta Italia. La penicillina, portata dagli Americani, era arrivata in Italia da poco e la tbc non era ancora stata debellata. I ricoveri in Sanatorio, quando andava bene (nel senso che si riportava a casa la pelle) duravano mesi e le visite, per infondati timori di contagio, erano scarse… anche (soprattutto) da parte dei familiari.

La radio era anche un indicatore dell’umore che aleggiava nella casa: “smorta la radio ch’è bà l’ha è nervos”. Quando “girava bene” si alzava il volume delle canzoni e le donne sovrapponevano, a quella dei cantanti, la loro voce… Ognuna apprendeva, così, parole e giusta intonazione, di tutte le canzoni preferite e le voci uscivano dalle finestre aperte, riecheggiando nelle strade. Fenomeno, oggi, completamente scomparso.

Quando la voce s’inceppava (u s’inchenta!) o si manifestava qualche guasto nel funzionamento, raramente l’apparecchio veniva portato dal tecnico (il servizio domicilio era di là da venire). Il rimedio più efficace era una botta (manata o pugno). Di solito funzionava.

Oggi si potrebbe tentare con il televisore, magari per ottenere l’effetto opposto

title: le biciclette della Minghina
body:
La bicicletta era il mezzo di trasporto per eccellenza, custodito dentro casa… nascosto, anzi riparato dietro il comò o la porta e protetto da un panno. Per tutti noi di quell’epoca, il film di De Sica “Ladri di biciclette” non era una storia ma un documentario di vita vissuta. Chi possedeva la bicicletta veniva già maggiormente considerato… aveva qualcosa in più dello stretto necessario. Era autonomo negli spostamenti. Nessuna distanza era impossibile. Le donne vi trasportavano le borse della spesa, quelle larghe e rigide di paglia e i bambini (di tutte le età) grazie ad un sellino anteriore… non c’era bambino che non si fosse intrappolato il piede tra i raggi della ruota… gli uomini trasportavano di tutto dagli attrezzi in spalla o appoggiati sul manubrio alle donne sedute sul cannone. Quelli a stipendio fisso la compravano di prima mano (la Vicini . . . la Bianchi. . ) gli altri si accontentavano di costruirle smontando e rimontando i pezzi di quelle vecchie scovati dalla “Minghina”, una sorta di emporio dei poveri dove si comprava e vendeva di tutto.

Talmente diffuso e necessario era il mezzo… che il governo di allora aveva tassato la bicicletta con un “bollo” che veniva esposto sul manubrio dentro un custodia tubolare di gomma. Anche quello era rischio: molti, infatti, “rimediavano” la bicicletta ma non i contanti per il bollo e si arrangiavano rubandolo.

I figli dei poveri non andavano alle scuole materne. Quelle comunali erano poco diffuse e quelle private erano troppo costose e per lo più gestite da religiose. Il popolo di sinistra era ideologicamente prevenuto ed anche pedagogicamente parlando era forte la convinzione che i bambini “stanno meglio a casa loro”. Quest’ultima teoria poi ritenuta di “destra” perché contraria all’emancipazione femminile che vuole giustamente le donne impegnate anche nella professione… in realtà nasce dal “popolino”.

Così passavo tutta la giornata con la mamma e trasportata in bicicletta avevo modo di “girare” tutta la città… osservare… ascoltare… le confidenze sui rapporti coniugali, le imprecazioni contro il carovita, le “chiacchiere” sulle donne “poco serie” o su quelle che si davano le arie (quella l’è na sburouna, la ia un poter di mé!). Affacciate sui banchi della Vecchia Pescheria o del mercato della frutta (allora in piazza Castelfidardo) o ferme con le amiche, le donne, rimanendo in sella alla bicicletta, sembravano dimenticarsi dei bambini e continuavano nei loro discorsi come se fossimo invisibili…

E proprio osservando i muri sono stata colpita dalla parola scritta, anzi da una parola in particolare. Immagino che la più parte dei bambini abbia scritto, per prima, la parola “ mamma”. Non è stato il mio caso. La prima parola che ho imparato a scrivere è stata quella che, a cinque anni, ho visto impressa in stampatello col gesso, nei muri, incisa nei portoni di ferro… ovvero la definizione del sesso femminile, quattro lettere, la prima “effe” l’ultima “a”. Ho studiato le lettere per giorni, ad una ad una… facili la I e la A , media difficoltà la F… decisamente difficile la G. Appena pronta ho ridisegnato, ignara della corrispondenza, la parola sui mattoni rossi del pavimento di casa usando il gesso preso dal Cantiere di fronte.

Poi, giustamente orgogliosa mi son messa ad urlare: “Anch’io so scrivere!” La reazione della mamma mi fece capire che avrei dovuto affidare alla scuola il compito della mia istruzione.

Il rischio di perdere anzi di confondere la propria identità culturale era più forte per i bambini che vivono in centro rispetto quelli della periferia. I genitori che pure si rivolgevano a noi nell’unico modo con cui sapevano esprimersi e cioè in dialetto impedivano a noi bambini di parlarlo sapendo che a scuola la lingua dialettale ci avrebbe penalizzato soprattutto nella scrittura della lingua italiana. I bambini poveri di città si ritrovavano a scuola con bagaglio linguistico ridotto e spesso improbabile nei significati. Si traduceva dal dialetto all’italiano in senso letterale: è credenzon diventava il credenzone, la bugheda la bucata, è stuvadein lo stuvatino. Una vera e propria minoranza linguistica. Le compagne usavano termini a noi sconosciuti come “iniezione”… mentre per noi poveri catarrosi c’erano solo le “punture” quelle che ci faceva qualche parente mani callose, unghie nere, usando la siringa di vetro bollita sul gas o sulla stufa, nel contenitore di alluminio. La “premura” per noi era la pressia… il superfluo… il dippiù.

Ed il linguaggio non era la sola cosa che ci distingueva. . La Scuola Elementare Farrrari di fronte l’omonimo Giardino era frequentata dall’elite cittadina. I poveri erano un’eccezione, come tale accettata. Le compagne figlie di professionisti, commercianti o nobili decaduti, ci guardavano dubbiose, diffidenti. Si salvavano, tra noi, sono quelle inaspettatamente “brave nel profitto”.

Quando ancora tutti gli alunni delle scuole elementari di Rimini portavano il grembiule nero; alla Ferrari il grembiule era di un azzurro chiaro modello predefinito da realizzarsi artigianalmente con stoffa venduta in via esclusiva alle “Quattro Stagioni”, negozio “chic” sotto i portici di piazza Tre Martiri. Il mio grembiule, confezionato dalla zia sarta con gli avanzi della stoffa dei clienti…aveva un colore più simile al blu che all’azzurro. La maestra me lo faceva graziosamente notare tutte le mattine, a voce alta, davanti le compagne. Arrossivo ed ingoiavo.

Le compagne avevano l’astuccio in pelle con chiusura a cerniera, matite colorate: quattro le sfumature del verde, tre quelle del rosso e così via. Io avevo l’astuccio di legno, appartenuto a mio fratello che lo aveva avuto da un amico più vecchio, sei colori essenziali, lunghezza cinque centimetri. I “colori” (pitturini) si restringevano ad occhio anche perché mancando il temperamatite non erano rare le volte in cui la punta “si faceva” col coltello di cucina.

Nell’aula della prima elementare vi erano quattro file di banchi, simmetriche e parallele La disposizione cambiò con l’arrivo della nipote della Direttrice. Sapendo già leggere e scrivere, iniziò la prima elementare nel mese di dicembre, fu nominata subito capoclasse dalla maestra ed ebbe un banco distaccato dagli altri, posto al centro, di fronte la cattedra.

Come ho ricordato negli appunti precedenti, abitavo con la mia famiglia in un’unica stanza nel palazzo di Via Cairoli, sopra l’allora Cinema Italia. La mattina scendevo, mi fermavo sugli scalini del portone d’ingresso e aspettavo la maestra che abitava in Via Bonsi per fare insieme il tratto di strada che portava alla scuola Ferrari. La maestra, dunque, sapeva come e dove abitavo.

Non dimeno il primo tema che diede alla mia classe fu “Le ore liete che trascorro nella mia cameretta”… seguito da “Prima gita con papà”.

Nel banco non ci si poteva atteggiare liberamente, le posizioni venivano impartite dalla maestra; in prima: braccia tese lungo i fianchi, in seconda: braccia unite dietro la schiena, in libertà: braccia conserte appoggiate sul tavolo. Il banco delimitava ogni singola postazione. Potevamo muovere la testa ma non le gambe; potevamo alzarci al momento della ricreazione, per andare in bagno, previa autorizzazione richiesta con il braccio alzato ed anche in un’altra circostanza. La maestra ci aveva spiegato che, in segno di rispetto, quando entrava in aula un adulto, era bene che le alunne si alzassero in piedi. Qui ho ricevuto, dalla scuola, la prima vera lezione di “classe”. S’affaccia sulla porta la maestra dell’aula di fronte: tutte in piedi. Entra, senza bussare, la direttrice: tutte in piedi. Entra il bidello: mi alzo solo io! La maestra mi guarda e, con un misto tra insofferenza e irritazione, mi riprende: “per il bidello non serve alzarsi!”. Naturalmente, data l’età, non ero in grado di fare grandi ragionamenti. Ma percepivo, quasi fisicamente, un forte senso di malessere: se era considerato niente il bidello, escluso perfino dal novero degli “adulti” quando nel mio immaginario era collocato tra coloro che avevano una “posizione” importante, uno stipendio sicuro… mio babbo manovale precario cosa era? Le compagne si sarebbero alzate al suo ingresso?

Mi rendo conto di fare il verso a De Amicis … ma le cose, negli anni cinquanta, stavano così! La mia è la generazione che, dal calamaio, è passata all’email…d al lume ad acetilene ad Internet… dal gabinetto con la “turca” alla vasca idromassaggio. Ci sarebbe da chiedersi se la stessa evoluzione sia avvenuta nei rapporti sociali ma questo è altro tema…

title: Rifiutare il concetto di retromarcia
body:
San Marino, 6 aprile 2013 - CURIOSO parcheggio quello effettuato stamattina, nel centro di Borgo Maggiore, a San Marino: una Fiat 500 sul cofano di un'Audi.

Quello che sembra un montaggio fotografico in realtà è avvenuto veramente e, per fortuna, non ha avuto nessuna conseguenza per i proprietari dei due mezzi.

La Fiat era guidata da un anziano che si era recato alle vicine poste ed ha lasciato l'auto in sosta nei pressi dell'ufficio. Al momento della partenza l'uomo, con ogni probabilità, deve avere ingranato la marcia sbagliata: anziché la retro ha infilato la prima. Il problema è che ha sfondato il parapetto e sul davanti c'era il vuoto, con una serie di auto parcheggiate proprio lì sotto. La Fiat si è fermata su una di queste. Dopo qualche peripezia l'autista dell'utilitaria è riuscito a uscire dal mezzo in bilico, senza aver subito nessuna ferita.

L'autista dell'Audi non era all'interno della sua macchina, quindi nessun problema nemmeno per lui. Certo non deve essere stata una bella sorpresa arrivare e trovare un'auto parcheggiata sul cofano della propria macchina. Lo spettacolare incidente ha subito attirato una folla di curiosi.

Il posto è intervenuta una pattuglia della Polizia civile che ha poi fatto rimuovere il veicolo in 'divieto'.

title: Jesús Part I: a childhood story between sheeps, wolves, mountains and hunger.
body:
Jesús was a brunette, skinny, swarthy child who used to work as a shapeherd.

He spent his childhood going over steep mountains and lush valleys, trying to find the best grass for his flock of sheeps, growing and looking after them the best way he knew.

However, that lifestyle was not as calmed and peaceful as it may appear: he would have to protect the sheeps and himself from the starving wolves which silently tried to feed on them.

Moreover, hunger was not the only enemy he would fight: everybody remembers '40s as the worst decade due to the post-war period in Spain. People could barely eat and Jesús case was not the exception: his bosses, which he describes as 'thieves', paid him the ridiculous salary of a small piece of bread a day. How can a child grow up in such conditions?!

While tricking wolves and hunger and gaining understanding of life and nature, no time would he get for literacy or school education -what, nevertheless, was the last of his problems...

title: Jesús Part II: a youth story in urban areas
body:
Jesús finally managed to move from a village in which he felt trapped and a life that would never give him what he always wanted and deserved and move to Madrid –capital of Spain and centre of a dictatorship regime beneficial for some and secretly criticised by the majority.

When in Madrid, he worked for a long, long time as a door-to-door salesman: ‘best cheese and all kinds of cold meat, ma’am!!!’ would he claim, with a smiling face and the self-confidence of a man whose future will bring nothing but bright days.

The street vending provided him the opportunity to travel all around Spain: meeting lots of different people, having friends everywhere and getting to know the variety of the Spanish architecture and landscapes (always breath-taking, always majestic) is what he would highlight and most enjoyed of his full of adventures life.

An advice? Never harm others –so they will not harm you.

title: Burgos, head of Castilla, land of the Cid
body:
Villagalijo, a village in the province of Burgos, is where Emilio was born. Approximately 50 inhabitants used to live there, mainly dedicated to farm work -occasionally hard (particularly during the cold winters), but usually gratifying and rewarding: ‘I never lacked of anything’, Emilio says. And one can definitely notice the satisfaction lying beneath his indelible smile.

Sadly, war took place in the ‘30s. And post-war period was far from repairing things. So emigration happened. And youngsters perceived a wider range of opportunities in urban areas than in the rural ones.

So, nowadays, Villagalijo is inhabited by 3 people. And farms are empty, land is unworked and grass grows wild and free wherever it fancies.

title: Nobody could divide what school has united!
body:
Nieves and Miguel, natural form Cantabria, met one another in their rural school. The uni-gender classrooms (either boys or girls) couldn’t prevent a young love that continued increasing over the years.

Their love story, however, was threatened by the presence of another girl, whose family was close to Miguel’s. Both families agreed to marry their two children but Miguel, firm and nonconformist, decided himself to bet on his future with Nieves.

‘What will you do with your son?’, his concerned uncle asked. ‘Let him be’, his father conceded.

Consequently, Nieves and Miguel could happily marry, what resulted in several children, who grew up and had their own, making up a great family and achieving a balanced, full of love old age.

title: But when has she been born?!
body:
‘As Spain is a country with a strong catholic tradition, children in the past where named after the saint of the corresponding day.

But my own case was priceless: I was born in the night between 11th and 12th of August of 1930 and neither my parents nor the doctor were sure to which of the days my birth belonged. So, they had two possible names for the new born baby girl: Clara or Hilaria.

Thank God they finally decided to call me Clara (what, by the way, means light or clear)!!!’

title: Chilhood mischiefs
body:
Clara used to live in a country house next to a gypsum factory. Thus, all her family was working there. 

The fact that she was the younger girl of 7 siblings implied that she grew up being the spoiled girl of the family, protected and loved by all. 

Her childhood in the countryside is full of funny and entertaining stories, like the list of them she has about the days when she, together with her older sisters, would steal figs, blackberries and other fruits from other people’s garden.
Those people, fed up of these mischiefs, decided to wait for them, with a stick in their hands, to chase them away whenever they pop into their gardens. 

Nobody finally dared, however, to graze her with the stick, fearing the consequences of bothering the youngest of so many siblings.

title: XX and XXI century chilhood
body:
Valentina was born in Ciudad Real. She has always had a strong character and been a bit naughty so, as a child, the teachers used to hit her hand with a ruler –typical punishment in Spain in the past. You had to let them hit you because, if you dared to move away your hand, they would hit you stronger.

We focus our conversation on comparing present and past children. Although she thinks childhood nowadays is easier, and she prefers the current situation, she feels kids now are a bit more disrespectful. ‘Nothing special’, she justifies, ‘but it is true that they refer to old people like ‘hey, ya!’ or say their teacher is an idiot, what would never have happened decades ago’.

However, she has two Chinese grandchildren, fruit of the current globalisation, which was also inconceivable when she was a child, which don’t cross such lines and she loves more than anything.

title: The Communist regime humanity
body:
The communism regime – the human dignity and the respect between people

Mrs. Eugenia Popa was an English teacher and she was one of the seniors interviewed in the frame of the Romanian Laboratory of Memory. She presend us a very interseting story from the communist period, a story which demonstrates that even in one of the worst political regime, the totalitarian ones, like the Romanian Communism, there can be good people, who can have good intentions and try to help the other.


In the communist period, Mrs. Popa obtained through a fair competition an important function in this times: the chief of cabinet and protocol the Communist Party Committee in Bacau county. She accepted that function because she belived that from these position she could help ordinary people and she did it. She remembered that, at some point, she received a call from a citizen who was very upset. Those man suffered ”the consequences of a injustice” – in the block of flats, where he was living were no heat anymore (because of a measures that promotes saving gas) and all the people, including him and his family were freezed because of the cold. He started to insult Mrs. Popa, as well as the whole Communist Party, but she remained calm and continued to listen him. Man was surprised when he saw that Mrs. Popa did not interrupted the conversation and did not insulted him, as the other persons which he had spoken before. She wanted to help him, so she asked him from what central heating they used to receive heat. She did not ask for other details, because she knew that if some individuals would discover the indentity of the man, he probably would have some problesms after that. Mrs. Popa told him to call over a half an hour and if the problem will not be solved until then, he can insult her, but if they will start to receive heat, he have to apologize because she is not gulty that someone else did not realize his/her duty in a proper way. Then, she called the director of the central heating, number 54 and after 15 minutes, the citizen called back, saying that the problem was solved and he thanked Mrs. Popa.

\tShe belives that what matters the most in a society, regardless of the political regime is the education, the character, the dignity, and qualities of a person, because if you can ”get inside in a peron’s soul” , you can win very much and you will become more happier knowing you helped someone. She personally met, during the communist period, 2 kinds of people (people who were members or had to do with the Communist Pary): some of they were educated and respected the perons for what they were and other who though that the perons were important and deserved respect only because the job (function) they had. This kids of people existed also in the transition period, when for some people, who lost their jobs in sevreal industrial companies which have close off, it was very difficult to adapt at a different society and start over again and they exist even today. She considers that the actions of the leaders have to be oriented by the justice and it is very important that everyone try to understand the other individuals and their needs.


In her opinion, the communist regime had both good and bad parts: good ones because all people had stable jobs and the State offered them houses and bad ones because in that period, many intellectuals and political leaders died in prisons or were persecutated by ”Securitate”. However, as she said: “Regardless of the society in which we live and about we are talking, in the centre of the actions do not stand the political program of the party, not even those of the society, but the behaviour, understanding and the of human action.” As Mrs. Popa said, if we want a better society, we have to improve our manners, because this kind of education is the most precious.

Link to the interview: https://youtu.be/pziAIalaloY

title: XIX - XX Century: Anzio land of internal migration
body:
Mr. Savese comes from a family who’s been living in Anzio for 25 generations.

His first ancestor in living memory is the brigand Matteo Savese who set sail from Capri island by boat and then landed on the little harbour city south of Rome.

In 1825 Anzio was nearly uninhabited. The city has gradually developed thanks to the arrival of different people coming from the territories dominated by the Church and the ones under the Spanish Crown (Bourbons Kingdom in the South of Italy) before Italy’s Unification.




More than a century later, during World War II, Anzio was the historical scenario where American troops landed to free Italy from the nazi-fascist occupation. Such event entailed the leaving of many families from their home looking for a temporary arrangement in other Regions.

Once the conflict was over, people came back with several friends and parents from the hosting Regions in particular from the South and from the Adriatic coast.

What made Anzio the city we know today is the encountering and the collaboration of different peoples in several historic moments between XIX and XX century and it is the reflection of how Italy has developed through the encounter of different peoples.

title: Tunisi - Anzio. One way.
body:
Belgalem arrived in Italy in 1981. He was 27 years old and he had the chance to be hosted in Anzio by some relatives. He approached the coast by ferry. The situation was hard at the beginning. He started working in the agriculture field thanks to some contacts he had made in Tunisi. He learned Italian working day by day.

He has good memories of Tunisi and he goes back often there to visit his family. He has three children living in Anzio, and he is happy to see them grow but at the same time he regrets not having taught them to speak Arab.


He is well integrated in the community of Anzio and keeps on observing Muslim traditions.

“Anzio is the city where I became an independent man” he loves to say and he considers migration something that has been occurring since forever and it is a resource for the hosting country.

title: How was the work in Communism?
body:
We worked all day long. This is a photo of an interview about Communism in Romania. This woman has an interesting story.


She told us about her work. She was afraid of her boss...everytime! She was working under stressful conditions, had a strict outfit, a fix programme and no right to opinion. But one day, she faced her boss and she realized that he is not really awful. He seemed to be just a very serious person, maybe occasionally grumpy, but not a bad person. After this "discovery" she started to work more relaxed.

This is the story of all average workers in the Communist regime. It was a good thing  that everybody had to go to work. Rate of unemploiment was very low. Factories were full. But, sometimes were run by untrained people to economical disaster. 

In my opinion, once, life was more hard and more strict than it is today. A human had many worries, many suffering and many shortcomings, but their stories are very deep and unforgettable. I consider that they were powerful  and mature people. They lived during some wars and some of them participated at them or at the Revolution from December 1989, which caused the collapse of the Romanian Communism.

Link to the interview:  https://youtu.be/3NAEVYPThI0

title: Nichita Stănescu
body:
I took a photo with Nichita Stănescu's portrait (hanged on a wall of one  interviewes' house).  Our seniors have at home many old books and pictures, some of them since the communist period, which are very interesting!

Nichita Stanescu  was one of the most important Romanian poets, receiving seven awards during his career. Some of his most known poetry volumes are: "Sensul iubirii", "O viziune a sentimentelor", "Oul si sfera", "Opere imperfecte" , " Un pamant numit Romania" etc.

He was born in Ploiești and spent his childhood in Drajna (the birthplace of his grandparents).

title: The black car
body:
The black car

I'm still thinking about the story of this old woman and I still feel the thrill of fear that she has sent us durring the interview. She told us how in her childhood, she and other people from the village were afraid of the black car that steals children. With tears in her eyes she told us how her husband which died in that period screamed at her to run away from this car and go in a safe place until it passes.  This black car, the car used by State police for arresting people, became a symbol of Communism oppresion.  

She was married with the owner of a restaurant before the Communist Party got the power.  Owners and other rich people were hunted by the communists, they were arrested and obliged to give their fortune to the State.  If they refused, they  were all gone to prison.  All educated people in high positions were replaced by untrained, sometimes illiterate, but Communist Party members. 

She told me the story of her husband run from this black car. He always slept dressed in warm clothes. Somebody from the house was on the watch all the time. If the car apeared, he run and hide in a neighbour's house attic.

After this hunt stoped, this kind of people were not allowed to have jobs according to their training. You can allways found a teacher, a priest or an engineer digging ditches or cleaniing toilets. Her husband was sent to work in the forrest to cut wood.

Now, I wonder if it's worth to live in a place where all the leaders do is to scare people and steal their freedom, happiness and in the end, their lifes.

 Link to the interview: https://youtu.be/QlsJD7CMjEA

title: Our past matters !
body:
Hi ! My name is Trascau Melania Ioana and I have to say that iRemember project is absolutely amazing ! In Drajna, our meetings are about learning new things . Why do I say that ? Because since this project began, I found out how my parents and my grandparents were raised, what the rules were and I was truly surprised. The people I worked with are special because of the passion for History, our history ! I am thankfull to be a part of the iRemember project and I know that, in time,  this period of my life will be an amazing memory ! 

During the Online Training for Students and the Laboratory of Memory realized in the frame of iRemember project we learned many new things; one of them regarded the Romanian Communism and we discovered many surprising things. The seniors which we interviewed had each one interesting stories - they presented us both parts of the communist regime - the bad effects that it had, but also the good ones. During this project, I met many people, both young and seniors, which I talk and we finished on sharing personal experience. Also, we started to create links between generations and to understand better the seniors, their lifes and the Romanian Communism, in general.

title: The Romanian Laboratory of Memory
body:
Thanks to Euro Adult Educatin Association which brought iRemember project to Drajna: six young people had the opportunity to learn recent history directly from the people that lived it.



In this Laboratory of Memories, young Andrada Irimia, 14 years old, learned from Vasilica Anonescu, 92 years old, about how land owners lost everything they had at the beginning of Communism, and how they lived in fear not to be arrested by political police. They always came by a black car, which became the symbol of the oppression.

The other students who partcipated at the Romanian Laboratory of Memory are: Silviu Irimia (18 years old), Melania Trascau (14 years old), Roberta Francu (17 years old), Ana Madalina Simion (17 years old), Alexandru Bratu (16 years old). Also, the other senios, which told us very interesting stories from the Communist period are: Eugenia Coman (76 years old), Marin Vacarelu (62 years old), Ioan Popa (69 years old) and Eugenia Popa (68 years old).

title: The communism...was it really bad? The education case.
body:
Mr. Ion Popa was during the communism period a teacher in a village close to where he was living. He remembered that the communist regime was a very difficult period, especially because of the rationing, the controlled distribution of all the resources, goods and services. Each person received ’’ration coupons which allowed people to purchase a certain amount of a product each month”. He thinks that the biggest problem from that period, which affected the major part of the population, was the lack of bread. He says: ’’I lived in Drajana de Sus, but I commuted to Coros. Here I did not receive bread, because I was not a resident of this village. Also, I did not receive bread neither in Drajna, because I was working at Coros.” He was forced to go to Bucharest weekly for two years to pick up bread, since that was the only place where he could obtain bread, but also with restrictions.


Although, Mr. Popa has suffered in the communist period he said that bad things did not happened only in the communist regime and he gives us an example: ’’in our village, Drajan de Sus, the people back then decided to build schools close to the children and to the village they were lived in. Thus, the pupils did not walk a long distance, sometimes through rain, and they saved time for others activities too. Mr. Popa told us that that in the communist period there were three marginal primary schools built in Drajna. Both during the communist regime and during the transition period these schools were operational, but about 7 years ago they were shut down. Thus, the pupils who had their homes near the schools have to now commute” because the 2 minibuses that were bought did not solve the problem. As former teacher who has known the curricula from the communist regime and has information about the present one, Mr. Popa believes that this one is overloaded and the children do not have time for themselves. He see also the good part of the communism, in contrast with the current capitalism: back then, the pupils went to school and learned to have a better life; now, many children drop out the school because of drugs, bad legislation and also parent’s negligence. Furthermore, in the communist period everyone had a stable job, unlike today. It was hard for many people to adapt post-communism to the new conditions and the labour market, aspect highlighted by the older people who sometimes feel nostalgia for communist regime. Mr. Popa considers that young people currently do not have enough time for their personal lives and the children do not have a pleasant childhood nowadays: ’’Now, children do not have childhood. I lived in communism, but I have a childhood and I enjoyed it very much.”

title: Sensali: the warm welcome to foreigners and immigrants
body:
The openness of the city of Anzio towards the rest of the world reflects the positive and warm approach its inhabitants always reserved for foreigners and migrants.

To be more specific this mentality turned out to be a real job.

The “sensali” were the ones you had to talk with in order to get to know which accommodations were available during your stay at the time when travel agencies were still far to be invented.


Finding them was not difficult at all. You just had to reach "Pia square" (heart of the city life) and there you could meet them in front of the newsstands.

They used to work from dawn till dusk, shouting: “Rooommms and appartmeeents ready to rent !!!”

once they grabbed the attention of the migrant, they would immediately accompany the foreigner to the potential final accommodation.


"Le Senzali"

title: Having a conversation with the world: a secret passage under the sea
body:
The coming of telecommunications represents one of the most significant accomplishments of modern times development. It is hard to realize how many things have changed in the daily life of everyone. Not just global, maritime and air trade would be trickier to manage but all the communication and information sources would result extremely restricted.

For Anzio, the first encounter with the “international communications” occurred on 1925, the year when the Italcable station was established. The undersea telegraphic cables were made up by an electric copper conductor protected by jute and wireframe.




Anzio was chosen instead of Rome thanks to its peaceful and secure environment. Giovanni Carosio – Italcable founder – built a monumental station overlooking the sea ready to bear the connections between Anzio and the rest of the world.



The main connections were:

a)\tMalaga and the whole South America (Las Palmas, Montevideo, Rio de Janeiro);

b)\tBarcelona and the whole North America (Azores islands then up to New York);

c)\tLisbon and the whole Northern Europe;

Anzio has been the first gate for Italian people meant and realized to have modern dialogue with the world. A concrete heritage for the new generations.

title: The culture, the communist regime and the aftermath
body:
Interview Marin Vacarelu

Mr. Marin Vacarelu has been for 22 years the director of the Cultural Centre from Drajna, but he has worked in the field for approximatively 45 years. Hence, he is closely acquainted with the cultural field from both periods: the communist one and the current, democratic one. He started to work at the Cultural Centre after the Revolution in December 1989, when Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife were executed. Mr. Vacarelu remembered a story which he lived during the communist period: ’’we were at the county stage of the National Festival ’’Cantarea Romaniei” at Ploiesti (...) at a certain moment, I had the idea to recite a poem written by Adrian Paunescu, ’’Copii de tarani”, poem which describe the life of some countryside people who managed to learn at better schools. In that period, Adrian Paunescu and his poetry were forbidden by law. After I recited the poem, applauses followed and I was pleased with how I recited it. But, at some moment, someone was came and – after many years I realized that he had good intentions – he told me to leave the room. After that, I understood that there were people (from ’’Securitate”, the Romanian police from the communist regime) in the room who were spying on us and everything that was happening on the scene.


During the communist period, in Romania also manifested ’’the personality cult of the leader”, an idea that Ceausescu had after he returned from some visits in China and Korea, where he saw the effects of the Cultural Revolution. Mr. Vacarelu considered that the men close to Ceausescu’s family glorified him and his wife and that sometimes they deformed the reality by telling him that the whole Romanian nation likes him. Mr. Vacarelu was able to see a part of the reality, because even if he followed a party school at Galati for 3 months, where he has learned more in depth the political program of the Romanian Communist Party, he also noticed that many people begun to distance themselves from the party and dislike Ceausescu’s leadership. The persons who suffered the most because of the Communist Party were, beside peasants who have lost the land all their goods, the workers that suffered in the transition period because many of the industrial companies where they worked started to close off for different reasons.

Returning to the culture, it was one of the few fields that allowed people to leave the country, but, of course, the artists were accompanied by some party’s men. Mr. Vacarelu believes that the ordinary Romanians were and are almost the same then and now, namely good and tolerant people, but who can be sometimes influenced by those who have the power. Mr. Vacarelu considers that, even if the Communism was a totalitarian regime, there were also some good aspects to it and if the party would have put into practice what the communist doctrine said, the situation would have been different. However, as he said: ’’I did not regret that period, maybe some regret it, but we continue to live our lives”.

Link to the interview: https://youtu.be/Hr0Ej-5SJFk

title: The Troubles: Unlocking the Past through Storytelling

The young people involved in the creative interpretation of these accounts were moved by being in the presence of these powerful stories, and felt it allowed them to better embrace and understand the reality and complexity of their own history. title: Café de Flore
body:
Le Café de Flore a vu le jour au début de la IIIe République, sans doute en 1887. Il doit son nom à une statue de la déesse du printemps, Flore, qui se dressait sur le trottoir d’en face.

A Saint-Germain-des-Prés, quartier où la création artistique et littéraire a toujours été très vivante, le Flore a vu passer de nombreux intellectuels, écrivains, peintres et cinéastes.

Guillaume Apollinaire investit les lieux dès 1913 et transforme le rez-de-chaussée en salle de rédaction. Il provoque la rencontre de Philippe Soupault, André Breton et Aragon qui formeront le groupe dadaïste.

Dans les années 1930, toute l’intelligentsia s’y donne rendez-vous. On peut y croiser Raymond Queneau, Robert Desnos, Léon-Paul Fargue, Marcel Carné et Jean-Louis Barrault.

Pendant l’Occupation, Jean-Paul Sartre et Simone de Beauvoir s’y installent. Dans le Paris d’après guerre, Juliette Gréco et Boris Vian incarnent une jeunesse ivre de liberté.

title: THE ROMANIAN COMMUNIST REGIME
body:
The Romanian Communist regime started to manifest since 1947, when the king of Romania, Mihai I, was forced to abdicate and the Communist party won the elections -1946 (in an unfair way) and came to power. Romania was a country were, it can say, the Communism had 2 periods: the first one, from 1948-1965, when the leader of the party and also of the country was Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej and the second one, after Dej's death, when started Nicolae Ceausescu's leadership.


Source: http://www.historia.ro/exclusiv_web/portret/articol/apostolii-lui-stalin-gheorghiu-dej-electricianul-patru-clase

Returning to Dej, his leadership was also divided in 2 periods: the first one, during from 1948 until 1958, when Romania was very close to USSR, but after 1958, when the Red Army withdrew from our territory, Gheorghiu-Dej started to cultive anti-soviet feelings and to distance from USSR. Gheorghiu-Dej is also known for his fight to eliminate important people from the Communist Party, which he considered that were or might become his opponents, like: Lucretiu Patrascanu, Ana Pauker, Vasile Luca, Teohari Georgescu.

Since the death of Dej, the leadership was owned by Nicolae Ceausescu, the person who introduced a new concept of communism, the national communism. Initially, Ceausescu was very popular among Romanian citizens, but also in the Occident, because of the policy which he promoted, especially in the foreign policy, where he challenged the authority of the Soviet Union in several times – as an example, in 1968, he refused to take part of the invasion of Czechoslovakia, although Romania was a member in the Warsaw Pact and furthermore, he criticized this action of the Soviet Union (in a public speech on 21 August 1968), saying that it was not the way they should behave with a friendly state. As a consequence, his popularity grew and more people started to like his leadership and the democratic leaders saw him like a man who could help them in the ”fight” with the Soviet Union, in particular with the Russian leader, Lenin. In the ’70, Ceausescu visited some countries like China and North Korea, where he saw the effects of the Cultural Revolution and he also assumed in Romania the personality cult of the leader - he and his family, especially his wife, being venerated by the whole Romanian people. Also, in the ’70 Romania was visited by democratic leaders, even the president of United States of America, Gerald Ford (in August 1975) and by people from IMF, which gave important amount of money to Romania, money used by Ceausescu for building several unique constructions (The House of People – the actual Palace of the Parliament, Transfagarasan, Danube-Black Sea Canal), Ceuasescu's dream being to make from Romania one of the most powerful countries in Europe. But the money were not enough for finish them and the Romanian dictator had to borrow outside, promising to repay all the money back to those countries.


Source: http://www.evz.ro/manifestarile-de-1-mai-obligatie-de-serviciu.html

Indeed, at the end of Ceausescu's leadership (1989), Romania was the only country which did not have external debts, but this thing was possible only with a lot of restrictions and worsening the people’s economic situation in the ’80 (the rationing – controlled distribution of all the resources, goods and services). Many historians believe that (the bad economic situation from ’80 which affected the most part of the population) was one of the reasons which led to he Revolution from December 1989, which started at Timisoara and the collapse of the Romanian communist regime.

\tRegarding the effects of the Communism in Romania, they were so many - some good, some disastrous. Nowadays a part of the population is nostalgic after the communist period and there are many people who do not understand why, since the Communism was a totalitarian regime, where the rights of the people were not respected. I think that we could not judge this people, but we have to try to understand why they think the Communism was good. I believe that the situation from Romania, in particular, was very different from the other European countries with the same regime, aspects that are not always presented in the History books. If we want to understand the Communism in its complexity we have to search other resources outside the books; we must listen the people who lived in that period and their memories. Thus, we might discover some things that could surprise us. Returning to those people who do not regret the communist times, I think that we could understand, at least partially, their opinion, if we look at the good things from the communist period, the less good from the transition period and the actual situation. In the whole communist period, people had a stable job, most of them working in industrial companies. Because of the collectivization, many people moved in towns and they received a job in these companies. Furthermore, the State offered them houses and all the conditions they needed (for example building of creches for the families with children in which both parents were working, a good education system). There were also 2 important holidays in Communism, days that the people enjoyed much: the National Day of Romania (23rd August - in the Communism) and 1st May, the Labor Day.


Source: https://ro.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rom%C3%A2nia_comunist%C4%83#/media/File:Defilare_23_August.jpg


Source: http://www.obiectiv.info/1-mai-in-perioada-comunismului-cum-sarbatoreau-romanii-ziua-muncii-pe-vremea-lui-nicolae-ceausescu_72502.html

It is true that the the human rights were not respected, especially the freedom of speech, but for the ordinary people this was not a tragedy (this was disturbing only the intellectuals and the other political leaders). They had their life, their job (even if sometimes it was not very well paid), their house because of the Communist Party, they had no reason to dislike it until the ’80, when were adopted some measures which led to a controlled distribution of the resources (the rationing) and the people’s conditions started to change – in the last years of Ceausescu’s leadership was a big lack of food – people could not even procure bread (because Ceausescu wanted to pay his foreign debts accumulated as a results of some great constructions – the most relevant example is the House of People, the second biggest building in the world, after the Pentagon - for its construction was destroyed a whole neighborhood and other buildings, in particular churches).


Source: https://ro.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palatul_Parlamentului#/media/File:Palatul_Parlamentului_1b.jpg

After the Revolution started in December 1989 and after the execution of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, a part of people lost their jobs because several industrial companies have close off. This people did not adapt to a new life, to the competition which come together with the democracy and the free market, the oldest with the technology and some young people cannot find a job. Many people said that the transition period was characterized by corruption and only the elites benefited by the collapse of the Communism and even after 2007, when we joined to the European Union, there were some people who said that our leaders are not interested in the society’s good, applying the European regulations in a superficial manner, thus they might be nostalgic after the Communism, where they had at least a stable life.

That the transition period was very difficult and controversial can be illustrated by the 6 "Mineriade" (protests of the Romanian miners which were violently repressed by the authorities) from: January, February, June 1990 , September 1991 , January and February 1999.


Source: http://www.mediafax.ro/20ani/stiri-din-anul/1999/vineri-22-ianuarie-1999-11-59-00-mineriada-1999-fuga-comandantilor-de-la-costesti-a-dezonorat-fortele-mi-armata-intervine-9182603

The negative aspects of the Romanian Communism are numerous: firstly, there were not individual freedoms and the human rights were not respected, although they existed in the Constitution. Secondly, in that period, were killed or imprisoned a lot of people, in particular people who opposed the party and the leader; the means of repression being very severe – the political police of the Romanian Communism was called ”Securitate” and it had the role to punish those who do not obey the Romanian Communist Party and to spy the whole population – for some people it was terrifying. In the communist period, people did not have access to information (people watched TV only a few hours, but the party propaganda was everywhere), could not leave the country (there were some exceptions, but with many restrictions), the lack of goods, services (heat, lighting), appliances etc.

In the communist period, Romania has lost many important intellectuals and political leaders, like: Iuliu Maniu, Constanin Argetoianu, Ion Caraion, Milhail Racovita, Mihail Manoilescu, Ion Antonescu, Mihai Antonescu, Gheorghe Alexianu, Constantin I.C. Bratianu, Dumitru Burilleanu, Sebastian Bornemisa who died in prisons or were executed. Apart them, there were many others who were imprisoned for several years: Ioan Balan, Petre Tutea, Ion Diaconu, Corneliu Coposu, Sergiu Grossu, Constantin Noica or some who had to leave the country. 


Also, during the December Revolution lost their life approximately 1200 persons, even children, circa 3200 were injured and almost 800 were arrested.


Source: http://www.historia.ro/exclusiv_web/general/articol/adevarul-revolu-ia-1989-rolul-lui-laszlo-tokes


Source: http://www.clujulcultural.ro/foto-noi-fotografii-cu-revolutia-din-21-decembrie-1989-de-la-cluj/

In conclusion, the Romanian Communist regime had a particular form, different from the other countries from Eastern Europe and even it had many bad effects, the people who lived or were born in the communist period do not regret that time, they do not consider that they have wasted their life working for the totalitarian state, represented by Ceausescu and the Communist Party and they are nostalgic about it (according to recent polls, almost 50% of the population), because they say that had certainly a house and a job, things which were not so stable in the transition period and neither nowadays for all people. But also are the other part of people, who does not want Communism anymore.


Source: http://www.modernism.ro/2014/12/20/eugen-moritz-revolutia-din-1989-de-la-cluj-napoca/ (Eugen Moritz, 1989, Cluj-Napoca)


Source: http://www.modernism.ro/2014/12/20/eugen-moritz-revolutia-din-1989-de-la-cluj-napoca/ (Eugen Moritz, 1989, Cluj-Napoca)

In my opinion, the Romanian Communist regime still have to be discovered, especially by the youngsters, but not only from History books or online, but also from the memories of the people who lived those times or people who had to do directly with the Romanian Communist Party. Thus, it will also be created linkages between 2 different generations and we will be able to understand each other better.

title: Mother's thumb
body:
Mother’s thumb

Dr. Mery Herouni-Sargsyan (her Father’s Story).

1915. A huge crowd forcibly expelled and deported from the Armenian town of Hagen in Cilicia, convoyed by horseback armed janissaries to the desert, has been melting away slowly. Flowing like a weak thin stream it was led to be lost in the hot arid sands. Almost everybody fell there, in a way.

A few survivors were left to die under the walls of the Arab village. They had no strength even to beg for a sip of water.

Her name was Hnazand. A month ago, she had a house, a family; she was young, healthy, beautiful woman. But now her nine year old son only left among all Family. All the rest fell died on the way. Sympathizing Christian Arabs gave them shelter and a bed in their yard for few days.

Hnazand passed her last pennies to son and whispered:

-\tGo, my son, may be in the bazaar they can give you something for this money.

Running breathless from the market, boy came to feed his exhausted mother. He believed that few carrots he have got, will save her.

Alas, she died.

He went with the Arabs out of the village to a deserted field, where men dug a shallow grave, and bury mother's body covering slightly with soil.

The boy mentally completely merged with the mound, where mother was buried, and this act has become full of a huge meaning for him, raising something very native, lightning his soul with flash of hope, inexplicable hope and memories ... Mother’s thumb was some evidence of the real existence of himself and all that reflects in his mind he had before.

The Arabs brought him home. In the morning, he opened his eyes and ran into the field, where was his mother's mound. Approaching the site, he saw the pieces of clothes, scattered all over the field. These were pieces of his mother torn clothes. Thumb disappeared, being dug up and robbed by jackals’ claws during the night.

title: The Troubles Revisited
body:
This gate and the stories within relate to the “Laboratories of Memory” held in Derry / L’Derry. These laboratories foreground the real life memories and stories of individuals, from all sides, who lived through the darkest days of the The Troubles. The drive was to present young people with a powerful learning and interactive experience away from the cold sterility of their history text books.

The key method employed was the facilitation of inter-generational storytelling workshops to allow for encounters between the young and more senior citizens. The main principle behind this was to allow for the first-hand accounts of those who have lived through and who have been affected by The Troubles to be shared – so that their stories could bring a tangible realism to the history of The Troubles for the young people.

The end material and the film available through the clickable link below, involves those original interviews and discussions and the young peoples’ creative interpretation of these moving and powerful first-hand accounts through film, poetry and even song.

The stories that have been engaged with and are here documented include the experiences of a woman whose husband was murdered by paramilitaries on the day of their son’s 18th birthday, a man who was part of a paramilitary group before changing his path, a nurse who attended to the dead and the dying on the streets of Derry on Bloody Sunday, another man who similarly witnessed the horror of that day, and a woman who was forced to move from her childhood home after community division reared its head. The young people were moved by being in the presence of these powerful stories, and all instantly acknowledged the worth of hearing such accounts in order to embrace the reality and complexity of their own history. Below is the link to the finished film, a song and a poem made up from original phrases spoken by those sharing memories. Read on, watch, listen and enjoy… 

The Film: Unlocking the Past

The Remembering (A poem created from the original spoken words of those sharing memories)

From days of innocence

We became aware of things changing:

We were caught in the crossfire of conflict.

We became anxious if strangers, wary of danger

We saw how suddenly lives were ripped away.

Some came with a gun in one hand and a bible in the other.

Then came the gunshots, the bombs, the gas, the bullets -

And the tears of tragedy.

We saw the young face down in death

And all we could hear was the crying.

What more could we have done?

We stood in grief here invading the dead

With our powerlessness to stop the killing.

The greatest tragedy of the Troubles was the Troubles

Something inhuman has happened here…

Now we fight to get rid of the hate.

To never forget the futility and senseless of war,

To never forget the rows upon rows of graves.

We must fight to change our story in our living story ghettos,

For there is no hierarchy of tragedy

It has all been tragic.

If we can change even one life

In the search for peace and reconciliation

We can begin a new story

That future generations can continue to write.

title: The Communism...was it really bad? The education case.
body:
Interview Mr. Popa

Mr. Ion Popa was during the communist period a teacher in a village close to where he was living. He remembered that the communist regime was a very difficult period, especially because of the rationing, the controlled distribution of all the resources, goods and services. Each person received ’’ration coupons which allowed people to purchase a certain amount of a product each month”. He thinks that the biggest problem from that period, which affected the major part of the population, was the lack of bread. He says: ’’I lived in Drajna de Sus, but I commuted to Coros. Here I did not receive bread, because I was not a resident of this village. Also, I did not receive bread neither in Drajna, because I was working at Coros.” He was forced to go to Bucharest weekly for two years to pick up bread, since that was the only place where he could obtain bread, but also with restrictions.

Although, Mr. Popa has suffered in the communist period, he said that bad things did not happened only in Communist  and he gives us an example: ’’in our village, Drajna de Sus, the people back then decided to build schools close to the children and to the village they were lived in. Thus, the pupils did not walk a long distance, sometimes through rain, and they saved time for others activities too. Mr. Popa told us  that in the communist period there were three marginal primary schools built in Drajna. Both during the communist regime and during the transition period these schools were operational, but about 7 years ago they were shut down. Thus, the pupils who had their homes near the schools have to now commute ”because the 2 minibuses that were bought did not solve the problem".  As former teacher who has known the curricula from the communist regime and has information about the present one, Mr. Popa believes that this one is overloaded and the children do not have time for themselves. He see also the good part of the Communism, in contrast with the current capitalism: back then, the pupils went to school and learned to have a better life; now, many children drop out the school because of drugs, bad legislation and also parent’s negligence. Furthermore, in the communist period everyone had a stable job, unlike today. It was hard for many people to adapt post-communism to the new conditions and the labour market, aspect highlighted by the older people who sometimes feel nostalgia for communist regime. Mr. Popa considers that young people currently do not have enough time for their personal lives and the children do not have a pleasant childhood nowadays: ’’Now, children do not have childhood. I lived in Communism, but I had a childhood and I enjoyed it very much."
